The client, Fountain Plc, utilizes a comprehensive Change Management Policy and Standard Operating Procedures to perform testing, review, and authorization of changes, including emergency changes. This policy was approved by their CIO, Sean John, in December 2021.

The policy outlines the entire process for initiating, testing, and approving changes to their IT systems. All changes, whether standard or emergency, are logged and managed through their ServiceNow platform. The policy also defines different types of changes, including standard changes, normal changes, emergency changes, application code changes, and configuration changes.

For emergency changes, which are defined as changes necessary to resolve critical issues that cannot wait for normal processing, verbal approval from the Change Advisory Board (CAB) or CIO is required before deployment. However, formal approval and documentation must be completed within 48 hours of the deployment.

The policy also outlines the roles and responsibilities of different stakeholders in the change management process, including the Change Requester, Change Manager, CAB, Implementer, and Tester. The CAB, consisting of senior IT members, is responsible for enforcing the change management controls.

Risk assessments are an integral part of their change request process. All changes are logged in ServiceNow and are categorized based on their potential impact. The risk level influences the depth of testing required and the level of approval needed.

Test cases and scripts are developed by the development team in collaboration with business users. These test cases are executed in a controlled test environment, and the results are meticulously documented. Any issues identified are resolved before the change is promoted to the production environment.

The required approval levels for each type of change are clearly outlined in their Change Management Policy. Approvals are logged in ServiceNow, and the CAB reviews and signs off on the changes before they are implemented. The version that is to be promoted is compared against the approved version as part of the change management process.

These controls have been in place since December 2021, when the Change Management Policy was approved. The audit was performed by Emma, a PwC auditor, for the Audit Year End of May 2024.

Fountain Plc Change Management 
Policy  
Purpose:  
The purpose of this policy is to ensure that all changes to Fountain Plc’s IT systems and 
services are managed efficiently, minimizing risks and maintaining the integrity and 
availability of IT services.  
Scope:  
This policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third -party vendors involved in the 
implementation of changes to IT systems and services.  
Policy Overview:  
1. Change Types:  
• Standard Change: Pre -approved, low -risk changes with established procedures.  
• Normal Change: Changes that require risk assessment and approval.  
• Emergency Change: Changes that must be implemented immediately due to critical issues.  
• Application Code Changes: Managed by developers. Changes must be version -controlled 
and follow standard change control processes.  
• Configuration Changes: Managed by system administrators. Changes to settings or 
tolerances that do not require code amendments must follow the same change control 
processes.  
2. Emergency Change Criteria:  
• Defined as changes necessary to resolve critical issues that cannot wait for normal 
processing.  
• Testing and Approval Timing: Must occur within 48 hours of promotion to production.  
• Determination: Control operators trace back to an emergency change request.  
3. Change Request Process:  
• Initiation: All change requests must be submitted through the ServiceNow platform.  
• Assessment: Each request will be assessed for impact, risk, and resource requirements.  
• Approval: Changes must be approved by the Change Advisory Board (CAB) or designated 
approvers.  
• Implementation: Approved changes will be scheduled and implemented by qualified 
personnel.  • Testing: Changes must be tested in a controlled environment prior to deployment.  
• Review: Post -implementation reviews will be conducted to assess the change outcome.  
4. Roles and Responsibilities:  
• Change Requester: Initiates and provides details for the change request.  
• Change Manager: Reviews requests, coordinates assessments, and facilitates CAB 
meetings.  
• CAB: Evaluates and approves changes, ensuring alignment with business objectives.  
• Implementer: Executes the change according to the approved plan.  
• Tester: Conducts testing to ensure the change meets acceptance criteria.  
5. Risk and Impact Assessment:  
• Changes will be assessed for potential impact on systems, users, and business operations.  
• Risk levels will be categorized as low, medium, or high, influencing the approval process.  
6. Testing Requirements:  
• Levels: Unit, integration, regression, and user acceptance testing based on scope and 
complexity.  
• Test Case Creation: Control operators develop test cases, scripts, and plans to ensure 
thorough testing.  
• Approval of Test Plans: Stakeholders, including IT and business representatives, must 
approve testing plans. Approvers are verified against a list of authorized individuals.  
7. Documentation:  
• All change requests, approvals, implementation plans, and test results must be 
documented in ServiceNow.  
• Detailed records will be maintained for audit and compliance purposes.  
• Changes are compared to approved versions using manual checks or version control 
software to ensure accuracy in promotion.  
8. Segregation of Duties:  
• Management ensures access to development, test, and production environments is 
appropriately segregated.  
• In emergencies, elevated accounts (e.g., firefighter) may be used with proper controls.  
9. Communication:  
• Stakeholders will be informed of upcoming changes, potential impacts, and post -
implementation results.  
• Emergency changes require immediate communication to affected parties.  
10. Emergency Change Process:  
• Emergency changes must be documented and justified in ServiceNow.  
• Post -implementation reviews are mandatory to evaluate the change’s effectiveness and 
impact.  11. Training:  
• Regular training sessions will be conducted to ensure all employees understand the 
change management process and their responsibilities.  
12. Promotion Process:  
• Changes must be promoted by someone other than the developer. In emergencies, 
temporary access may be granted.  
• Approval for Promotion: All promotions must adhere to established policies and 
procedures.  
Policy Compliance:  
Failure to comply with this policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including 
termination of employment or contract.  
Review and Updates:  
This policy will be reviewed annually and updated as necessary to ensure continued 
relevance and compliance with industry standards.  
Approval:  
This Change Management Policy has been reviewed and approved by the executive 
management of Fountain Plc.  
 
• Approved by: Sean John, CIO  
• Date of Approval: December 2021

Policy was approved.Emma: Who is responsible for enforcing these controls, and do they have the appropriate authority?

ServiceNow, conducting tests, and obtaining approvals from the Change Advisory Board (CAB).

that could disrupt core business operations. For these changes, verbal approval from the CAB or
CIO is required before deployment. Although the change is implemented immediately, we conduct
testing and document the change as soon as possible afterward. Formal approval and
documentation must be completed within 48 hours of the deployment.
Emma: How do you determine if a change qualifies as an emergency change?
John: The CAB retrospectively reviews the situation to determine whether the emergency criteria
were met. Whenever possible, we seek written approval after the deployment.
Emma: How do you ensure that all changes follow a consistent process, regardless of the type?
John: All changes, whether standard or emergency, are logged and managed through our
ServiceNow platform. We apply the same process across all in-scope applications to ensure
consistency in our change management procedures.
Emma: How do you handle changes to different types of applications, such as hosted applications,
SaaS solutions, or internally developed systems?
John: Regardless of the application type, whether hosted, SaaS, or internally developed, all
changes are categorized as either standard or emergency. They all follow the same change
management process as outlined in our policy.

depth of testing required and the level of approval needed.

users. These test cases are executed in a controlled test environment, and the results are

production environment.

Management Policy. Approvals are logged in ServiceNow, and the CAB reviews and signs off on the
changes before they are implemented.
Emma: How do you ensure that all relevant stakeholders have approved the testing cases, scripts,
and plans?
John: Approvals are tracked and logged within the change tickets in ServiceNow. Each stakeholder
records their approval as part of the workflow, and these are reviewed by the CAB before the
change is finalized.
Emma: How do you document and approve the results of testing procedures?John: The results of all testing procedures are documented in ServiceNow. Any issues that arise
during testing are logged and addressed before final approval is given.

compared against the approved version as part of the change management process.

environments?

mandates that changes must be promoted by someone other than the developer who made the
change.

John: The required approval levels are defined in our Change Management Policy. The CAB
initiates the approval process, and both the process owner and the CAB must sign off before a
change is promoted to production.

John: These controls have been in place since December 2021, when the Change Management
Policy was approved.Emma: Who is responsible for enforcing these controls, and do they have the appropriate authority?
John: The CAB, which consists of senior IT members, is responsible for enforcing the change
management controls. They are considered well-qualified and appropriate for this role.

consistency in our change management procedures.

SaaS solutions, or internally developed systems?

changes are categorized as either standard or emergency. They all follow the same change
management process as outlined in our policy.

depth of testing required and the level of approval needed.

change is finalized.

environments?

change.

Fountain Plc Change Management 
Policy  
Purpose:  
The purpose of this policy is to ensure that all changes to Fountain Plc’s IT systems and 
services are managed efficiently, minimizing risks and maintaining the integrity and 
availability of IT services.  
Scope:  
This policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third -party vendors involved in the 
implementation of changes to IT systems and services.  
Policy Overview:  
1. Change Types:  
• Standard Change: Pre -approved, low -risk changes with established procedures.  
• Normal Change: Changes that require risk assessment and approval.  
• Emergency Change: Changes that must be implemented immediately due to critical issues.  
• Application Code Changes: Managed by developers. Changes must be version -controlled 
and follow standard change control processes.  
• Configuration Changes: Managed by system administrators. Changes to settings or 
tolerances that do not require code amendments must follow the same change control 
processes.  
2. Emergency Change Criteria:  
• Defined as changes necessary to resolve critical issues that cannot wait for normal 
processing.  
• Testing and Approval Timing: Must occur within 48 hours of promotion to production.  
• Determination: Control operators trace back to an emergency change request.  
3. Change Request Process:  
• Initiation: All change requests must be submitted through the ServiceNow platform.  
• Assessment: Each request will be assessed for impact, risk, and resource requirements.  
• Approval: Changes must be approved by the Change Advisory Board (CAB) or designated 
approvers.  
• Implementation: Approved changes will be scheduled and implemented by qualified 
personnel.  • Testing: Changes must be tested in a controlled environment prior to deployment.  
• Review: Post -implementation reviews will be conducted to assess the change outcome.  
4. Roles and Responsibilities:  
• Change Requester: Initiates and provides details for the change request.  
• Change Manager: Reviews requests, coordinates assessments, and facilitates CAB 
meetings.  
• CAB: Evaluates and approves changes, ensuring alignment with business objectives.  
• Implementer: Executes the change according to the approved plan.  
• Tester: Conducts testing to ensure the change meets acceptance criteria.  
5. Risk and Impact Assessment:  
• Changes will be assessed for potential impact on systems, users, and business operations.  
• Risk levels will be categorized as low, medium, or high, influencing the approval process.  
6. Testing Requirements:  
• Levels: Unit, integration, regression, and user acceptance testing based on scope and 
complexity.  
• Test Case Creation: Control operators develop test cases, scripts, and plans to ensure 
thorough testing.  
• Approval of Test Plans: Stakeholders, including IT and business representatives, must 
approve testing plans. Approvers are verified against a list of authorized individuals.  
7. Documentation:  
• All change requests, approvals, implementation plans, and test results must be 
documented in ServiceNow.  
• Detailed records will be maintained for audit and compliance purposes.  
• Changes are compared to approved versions using manual checks or version control 
software to ensure accuracy in promotion.  
8. Segregation of Duties:  
• Management ensures access to development, test, and production environments is 
appropriately segregated.  
• In emergencies, elevated accounts (e.g., firefighter) may be used with proper controls.  
9. Communication:  
• Stakeholders will be informed of upcoming changes, potential impacts, and post -
implementation results.  
• Emergency changes require immediate communication to affected parties.  
10. Emergency Change Process:  
• Emergency changes must be documented and justified in ServiceNow.  
• Post -implementation reviews are mandatory to evaluate the change’s effectiveness and 
impact.  11. Training:  
• Regular training sessions will be conducted to ensure all employees understand the 
change management process and their responsibilities.  
12. Promotion Process:  
• Changes must be promoted by someone other than the developer. In emergencies, 
temporary access may be granted.  
• Approval for Promotion: All promotions must adhere to established policies and 
procedures.  
Policy Compliance:  
Failure to comply with this policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including 
termination of employment or contract.  
Review and Updates:  
This policy will be reviewed annually and updated as necessary to ensure continued 
relevance and compliance with industry standards.  
Approval:  
This Change Management Policy has been reviewed and approved by the executive 
management of Fountain Plc.  
 
• Approved by: Sean John, CIO  
• Date of Approval: December 2021

Fountain Plc Change Management 
Policy  
Purpose:  
The purpose of this policy is to ensure that all changes to Fountain Plc’s IT systems and 
services are managed efficiently, minimizing risks and maintaining the integrity and 
availability of IT services.  
Scope:  
This policy applies to all employees, contractors, and third -party vendors involved in the 
implementation of changes to IT systems and services.  
Policy Overview:  
1. Change Types:  
• Standard Change: Pre -approved, low -risk changes with established procedures.  
• Normal Change: Changes that require risk assessment and approval.  
• Emergency Change: Changes that must be implemented immediately due to critical issues.  
• Application Code Changes: Managed by developers. Changes must be version -controlled 
and follow standard change control processes.  
• Configuration Changes: Managed by system administrators. Changes to settings or 
tolerances that do not require code amendments must follow the same change control 
processes.  
2. Emergency Change Criteria:  
• Defined as changes necessary to resolve critical issues that cannot wait for normal 
processing.  
• Testing and Approval Timing: Must occur within 48 hours of promotion to production.  
• Determination: Control operators trace back to an emergency change request.  
3. Change Request Process:  
• Initiation: All change requests must be submitted through the ServiceNow platform.  
• Assessment: Each request will be assessed for impact, risk, and resource requirements.  
• Approval: Changes must be approved by the Change Advisory Board (CAB) or designated 
approvers.  
• Implementation: Approved changes will be scheduled and implemented by qualified 
personnel.  • Testing: Changes must be tested in a controlled environment prior to deployment.  
• Review: Post -implementation reviews will be conducted to assess the change outcome.  
4. Roles and Responsibilities:  
• Change Requester: Initiates and provides details for the change request.  
• Change Manager: Reviews requests, coordinates assessments, and facilitates CAB 
meetings.  
• CAB: Evaluates and approves changes, ensuring alignment with business objectives.  
• Implementer: Executes the change according to the approved plan.  
• Tester: Conducts testing to ensure the change meets acceptance criteria.  
5. Risk and Impact Assessment:  
• Changes will be assessed for potential impact on systems, users, and business operations.  
• Risk levels will be categorized as low, medium, or high, influencing the approval process.  
6. Testing Requirements:  
• Levels: Unit, integration, regression, and user acceptance testing based on scope and 
complexity.  
• Test Case Creation: Control operators develop test cases, scripts, and plans to ensure 
thorough testing.  
• Approval of Test Plans: Stakeholders, including IT and business representatives, must 
approve testing plans. Approvers are verified against a list of authorized individuals.  
7. Documentation:  
• All change requests, approvals, implementation plans, and test results must be 
documented in ServiceNow.  
• Detailed records will be maintained for audit and compliance purposes.  
• Changes are compared to approved versions using manual checks or version control 
software to ensure accuracy in promotion.  
8. Segregation of Duties:  
• Management ensures access to development, test, and production environments is 
appropriately segregated.  
• In emergencies, elevated accounts (e.g., firefighter) may be used with proper controls.  
9. Communication:  
• Stakeholders will be informed of upcoming changes, potential impacts, and post -
implementation results.  
• Emergency changes require immediate communication to affected parties.  
10. Emergency Change Process:  
• Emergency changes must be documented and justified in ServiceNow.  
• Post -implementation reviews are mandatory to evaluate the change’s effectiveness and 
impact.  11. Training:  
• Regular training sessions will be conducted to ensure all employees understand the 
change management process and their responsibilities.  
12. Promotion Process:  
• Changes must be promoted by someone other than the developer. In emergencies, 
temporary access may be granted.  
• Approval for Promotion: All promotions must adhere to established policies and 
procedures.  
Policy Compliance:  
Failure to comply with this policy may result in disciplinary action, up to and including 
termination of employment or contract.  
Review and Updates:  
This policy will be reviewed annually and updated as necessary to ensure continued 
relevance and compliance with industry standards.  
Approval:  
This Change Management Policy has been reviewed and approved by the executive 
management of Fountain Plc.  
 
• Approved by: Sean John, CIO  
• Date of Approval: December 2021
